column1: The Selma to Montgomery marches were three protest marches
column2: held in 1965
column3: along the 54-mile (87 km) highway from Selma
column4: Alabama
column5: to the state capital of Montgomery. The marches were organized by nonviolent activists to demonstrate the desire of African-American citizens to exercise their constitutional right to vote
column6: in defiance of segregationist repression; they were part of a broader voting rights movement underway in Selma and throughout the American South. By highlighting racial injustice
column7: they contributed to passage that year of the Voting Rights Act
column8: a landmark federal achievement of the civil rights movement.

column1: Southern state legislatures had passed and maintained a series of discriminatory requirements and practices that had disenfranchised most of the millions of African Americans across the South throughout the 20th century. The African-American group known as the Dallas County Voters League (DCVL) launched a voter registration campaign in Selma in 1963. Joined by organizers from the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC)
column2: they began working that year in a renewed effort to register black voters.

column1: Finding resistance by white officials to be intractable
column2: even after the Civil Rights Act of 1964 ended legal segregation
column3: the DCVL invited Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. and the activists of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC) to join them. SCLC brought many prominent civil rights and civic leaders to Selma in January 1965. Local and regional protests began
column4: with 3
column5: 000 people arrested by the end of February.  According to Joseph A. Califano Jr.
column6: who served as head of domestic affairs for U.S. President Lyndon Johnson between the years 1965 and 1969
column7: the President viewed King as an essential partner in getting the Voting Rights Act enacted. Califano
column8: whom the President also assigned to monitor the final march to Montgomery
column9: said that Johnson and King talked by telephone on January 15 to plan a strategy for drawing attention to the injustice of using literacy tests and other barriers to stop black Southerners from voting
column10: and that King later informed the President on February 9 of his decision to use Selma to achieve this objective.On February 26
column12: activist and deacon Jimmie Lee Jackson died after being shot several days earlier by state trooper James Bonard Fowler
column13: during a peaceful march in nearby Marion
column14: Alabama. To defuse and refocus the community's outrage

column17: called for a march of dramatic length
column18: from Selma to the state capital of Montgomery. Bevel had been working on his Alabama Project for voting rights since late 1963.

column1: The first march took place on March 7

column4: Amelia Boynton
column5: and others. State troopers and county possemen attacked the unarmed marchers with billy clubs and tear gas after they passed over the county line
column6: and the event became known as Bloody Sunday. Law enforcement beat Boynton unconscious
column7: and the media publicized worldwide a picture of her lying wounded on the Edmund Pettus Bridge.The second march took place March 9. Troopers
column8: police
column9: and marchers confronted each other at the county end of the bridge
column10: but when the troopers stepped aside to let them pass
column11: King led the marchers back to the church. He was obeying a federal injunction while seeking protection from federal court for the march. That night
column12: a white group beat and murdered civil rights activist James Reeb
column13: a Unitarian Universalist minister from Boston
column14: who had come to Selma to march with the second group. Many other clergy and sympathizers from across the country also gathered for the second march.

column1: The violence of "Bloody Sunday" and Reeb's murder resulted in a national outcry and some acts of civil disobedience
column2: targeting both the Alabama and federal governments.  The protesters demanded protection for the Selma marchers and a new federal voting rights law to enable African Americans to register and vote without harassment. President Lyndon Johnson
column3: whose administration had been working on a voting rights law
column4: held a historic
column5: nationally televised joint session of Congress on March 15 to ask for the bill's introduction and passage.

column1: With Governor Wallace refusing to protect the marchers
column2: President Johnson committed to do so. The third march started on March 21. Protected by 1
column3: 900 members of the Alabama National Guard under federal command
column4: and many FBI agents and federal marshals
column5: the marchers averaged 10 miles (16 km) a day along U.S. Route 80
column6: known in Alabama as the "Jefferson Davis Highway". The marchers arrived in Montgomery on March 24 and at the Alabama State Capitol on March 25. With thousands having joined the campaign
column8: 000 people entered the capital city that day in support of voting rights.

column1: The route is memorialized as the "Selma To Montgomery Voting Rights Trail"
column2: and is designated as a U.S. National Historic Trail. The Voting Rights Act became law on August 6

column1: At the turn of the 20th century
column2: the Alabama state legislature passed a new constitution that effectively disenfranchised most blacks and many poor whites by requirements for payment of a poll tax and passing a literacy test and comprehension of the constitution. Subjective application of the laws effectively closed most blacks out of politics. Selma is a major town and the seat of Dallas County
column3: part of the Alabama Black Belt with a majority-black population. In 1961
column4: the population of Dallas County was 57% black
column5: but of the 15
column6: 000 blacks old enough to vote
column7: only 130 were registered (fewer than 1%). At that time
column8: more than 80% of Dallas County blacks lived below the poverty line
column9: most of them working as sharecroppers
column10: farmhands
column11: maids
column14: but there were also teachers and business owners. With the literacy test administered subjectively by white registrars
column15: even educated blacks were prevented from registering or voting.Led by the Boynton family (Amelia
column21: the Dallas County Voters League (DCVL) tried to register black citizens during the late 1950s and early 1960s. Their efforts were blocked by state and local officials
column23: and the Ku Klux Klan. By the 1960s
column24: county officials and the Citizens' Council used such tactics as restricted registration hours; economic pressure
column28: and economic boycotts of black-owned businesses; and violence against blacks who tried to register. The Society of Saint Edmund
column29: an order of Catholics committed to alleviating poverty and promoting civil rights
column30: were the only whites in Selma who openly supported the voting rights campaign. SNCC staff member Don Jelinek later described this order as "the unsung heroes of the Selma March ... who provided the only integrated Catholic church in Selma
column31: and perhaps in the entire Deep South".In early 1963
column32: SNCC organizers Bernard Lafayette and Colia Liddel Lafayette arrived in Selma to begin a voter-registration project in cooperation with the DCVL. In mid-June
column33: Bernard was beaten and almost killed by Klansmen determined to prevent blacks from voting. When the Lafayettes returned to college in the fall
column34: SNCC organizers Prathia Hall and Worth Long carried on the work despite arrests
column36: and death threats. When 32 black school teachers applied at the county courthouse to register as voters
column37: they were immediately fired by the all-white school board.

column1: After the Birmingham church bombing on September 15
column3: which killed four black girls
column4: black students in Selma began sit-ins at local lunch counters to protest segregation; they were physically attacked and arrested. More than 300 were arrested in two weeks of protests
column5: including SNCC Chairman John Lewis.On October 7
column7: one of two days during the month when residents were allowed to go to the courthouse to apply to register to vote
column8: SNCC's James Forman and the DCVL mobilized more than 300 blacks from Dallas County to line up at the voter registration office in what was called a "Freedom Day". Supporting them were national figures: author James Baldwin and his brother David
column9: and comedian Dick Gregory and his wife Lillian (she was later arrested for picketing with SNCC activists and local supporters). SNCC members who tried to bring water to African Americans waiting on line were arrested
column10: as were those who held signs saying "Register to Vote". After waiting all day in the hot sun
column11: only a handful of the hundreds in the line were allowed to fill out the voter application
column12: and most of those applications were denied by white county officials. United States Justice Department lawyers and FBI agents were present and observing the scene
column13: but took no action against local officials.On July 2
column15: President Johnson signed the Civil Rights Act of 1964 into law
column16: prohibiting segregation of public facilities. Some Jim Crow laws and customs remained in effect in Selma and other places for some time. When activists resumed efforts to integrate Selma's eating and entertainment venues
column17: blacks who tried to attend the movie theater and eat at the hamburger stand were beaten and arrested.

column7: Judge James Hare issued an injunction forbidding any gathering of three or more people under the sponsorship of civil rights organizations or leaders. This injunction made it illegal for more than two people at a time to talk about civil rights or voter registration in Selma

column1: Since the rejection of voting status for the Mississippi Freedom Democratic Party delegates by the regular delegates at the 1964 Democratic National Convention in Atlantic City
column2: major tensions between SCLC and SNCC had been brewing. SCLC ultimately remained neutral in the MFDP dispute in order to maintain its ties with the national Democratic coalition. Many SNCC members believed they were in an adversarial position with an American establishment which they thought had scorned grassroots democracy. SNCC's focus was on bottom-up organizing
column3: establishing deep-rooted local power bases through community organizing. They had become distrustful of SCLC's spectacular mobilizations which were designed to appeal to the national media and Washington DC
column4: but which
column5: most of SNCC believed
column6: did not result in major improvements for the lives of African Americans on the ground.  But
column7: SNCC chairman John Lewis (also an SCLC board member)
column8: believed mass mobilizations to be invaluable
column9: and he urged the group to participate. SNCC called in Fay Bellamy and Silas Norman to be full-time organizers in Selma.Selma had both moderate and hardline segregationists in its white power structure. The newly elected Mayor Joseph Smitherman was a moderate who hoped to attract Northern business investment
column10: and he was very conscious of the city's image. Smitherman appointed veteran lawman Wilson Baker to head the city's 30-man police force. Baker believed that the most effective method of undermining civil rights protests was to de-escalate them and deny them publicity
column11: as Police Chief Laurie Pritchett had done against the Albany Movement in Georgia. He earned what was described as a grudging respect from activists.

column1: The hardline of segregation was represented by Dallas County Sheriff Jim Clark
column2: who used violence and repression to maintain Jim Crow. He commanded a posse of 200 deputies
column3: some of whom were members of Ku Klux Klan chapters or the National States' Rights Party. Possemen were armed with electric cattle-prods. Some were mounted on horseback and carried long leather whips they used to lash people on foot. Clark and Chief Baker were known to spar over jurisdiction. Baker's police patrolled the city except for the block of the county courthouse
column4: which Clark and his deputies controlled. Outside the city limits
column5: Clark and his volunteer posse were in complete control in the county.

column1: The Selma Voting Rights Campaign officially started on January 2

column4: and Chief Baker had stated he would not enforce the injunction. Over the following weeks
column5: SCLC and SNCC activists expanded voter registration drives and protests in Selma and the adjacent Black Belt counties.

column1: === Initiation and goals of the march ===
During a public meeting at Zion United Methodist Church in Marion on February 28 after Jackson's death
column2: emotions were running high. James Bevel
column3: as director of the Selma voting rights movement for SCLC
column4: called for a march from Selma to Montgomery to talk to Governor George Wallace directly about Jackson's death
column5: and to ask him if he had ordered the State Troopers to turn off the lights and attack the marchers. Bevel strategized that this would focus the anger and pain of the people of Marion and Selma toward a nonviolent goal
column6: as many were so outraged they wanted to retaliate with violence.The marchers also hoped to bring attention to the continued violations of their Constitutional rights by marching to Montgomery. Dr. King agreed with Bevel's plan of the march
column7: which they both intended to symbolize a march for full voting rights. They were to ask Governor Wallace to protect black registrants.

column1: SNCC had severe reservations about the march
column2: especially when they heard that King would not be present. They permitted John Lewis to participate
column3: and SNCC provided logistical support
column4: such as the use of its Wide Area Telephone Service (WATS) lines and the services of the Medical Committee on Human Rights
column5: organized by SNCC during the Mississippi Summer Project of 1964.Governor Wallace denounced the march as a threat to public safety; he said that he would take all measures necessary to prevent it from happening. "There will be no march between Selma and Montgomery
column6: Wallace said on March 6, 1965, citing concern over traffic violations. He ordered Alabama Highway Patrol Chief Col. Al Lingo to use whatever measures are necessary to prevent a march".

column3: an estimated 525 to 600 civil rights marchers headed southeast out of Selma on U.S. Highway 80. The march was led by John Lewis of SNCC and the Reverend Hosea Williams of SCLC
column4: followed by Bob Mants of SNCC and Albert Turner of SCLC. The protest went according to plan until the marchers passed by a Lehman Pontiac-Buick-GMC dealership and crossed the Edmund Pettus Bridge
column5: where they encountered a wall of state troopers and county posse waiting for them on the other side blocking parts of U.S. Route 80 and a John Deere dealership
column6: located at the 100th to 212th block of U.S. Route 80 East between Haisten's Mattress & Awning Company
column7: an used-car dealership
column8: Selma's Curb Market
column9: Selma's Glass House restaurant
column10: and a 15-cent Hamburgers drive-in restaurant.County sheriff Jim Clark had issued an order for all white males in Dallas County over the age of twenty-one to report to the courthouse that morning to be deputized. Commanding officer John Cloud told the demonstrators to disband at once and go home. Rev. Hosea Williams tried to speak to the officer
column11: but Cloud curtly informed him there was nothing to discuss. Seconds later
column12: the troopers began shoving the demonstrators
column13: knocking many to the ground and beating them with nightsticks. Another detachment of troopers fired tear gas
column14: and mounted troopers charged the crowd on horseback.Televised images of the brutal attack presented Americans and international audiences with horrifying images of marchers left bloodied and severely injured
column15: and roused support for the Selma Voting Rights Campaign. Amelia Boynton
column16: who had helped organize the march as well as marching in it
column17: was beaten unconscious. A photograph of her lying on the road of the Edmund Pettus Bridge appeared on the front page of newspapers and news magazines around the world. Another marcher
column20: was brutally beaten by a police officer during the march
column21: and needed seven stitches for a cut above her right eye and 28 stitches on the back of her head. John Lewis suffered a skull fracture. and he bore scars on his head from the incident for the rest of his life.  In all
column22: 17 marchers were hospitalized and 50 treated for lesser injuries; the day soon became known as "Bloody Sunday" within the black community.

column2: President Johnson issued an immediate statement "deploring the brutality with which a number of Negro citizens of Alabama were treated". He also promised to send a voting rights bill to Congress that week
column3: although it took him until March 15.SNCC officially joined the Selma campaign
column4: putting aside their qualms about SCLC's tactics in order to rally for "the fundamental right of protest". SNCC members independently organized sit-ins in Washington

column6: the following day
column7: occupying the office of Attorney General Nicholas Katzenbach until they were dragged away.The Executive Board of the NAACP unanimously passed a resolution the day after "Bloody Sunday"
column8: warning

column1: If Federal troops are not made available to protect the rights of Negroes
column2: then the American people are faced with terrible alternatives.  Like the citizens of Nazi-occupied France
column3: Negroes must either submit to the heels of their oppressors or they must organize underground to protect themselves from the oppression of Governor Wallace and his storm troopers.In response to "Bloody Sunday
column4:
labor leader Walter Reuther sent a telegram on March 9 to President Johnson, reading in part:Americans of all religious faiths, of all political persuasions, and from every section of our Nation are deeply shocked and outraged at the tragic events in Selma Ala., and they look to the Federal Government as the only possible source to protect and guarantee the exercise of constitutional rights, which is being denied and destroyed by the Dallas County law enforcement agents and the Alabama State troops under the direction of Governor George Wallace.
Under these circumstances, Mr President, I join in urging you to take immediate and appropriate steps including the use of Federal marshals and troops if necessary, so that the full exercise of constitutional rights including free assembly and free speech be fully protected.


== Second march: Turnaround Tuesday" ==

column2: King
column3: Nash
column4: and others began organizing a second march to be held on Tuesday
column5: March 9
column6: 1965. They issued a call for clergy and citizens from across the country to join them. Awakened to issues of civil and voting rights by years of Civil Rights Movement activities
column7: and shocked by the television images of "Bloody Sunday
column8:
hundreds of people responded to SCLC's call.
To prevent another outbreak of violence, SCLC attempted to gain a court order that would prohibit the police from interfering. Instead of issuing the court order, U.S. District Court Judge Frank Minis Johnson issued a restraining order, prohibiting the march from taking place until he could hold additional hearings later in the week.
Based on past experience, some in SCLC were confident that Judge Johnson would eventually lift the restraining order. They did not want to alienate one of the few southern judges who had displayed sympathy to their cause by violating his injunction. In addition, they did not yet have sufficient infrastructure in place to support the long march, one for which the marchers were ill-equipped. They knew that violating a court order could result in punishment for contempt, even if the order is later reversed.  But some movement activists, both local and from around the country, were determined to march on Tuesday to protest both the Bloody Sunday" violence and the systematic denial of black voting rights in Alabama. Both Hosea Williams and James Forman argued that the march must proceed and by the early morning of the march date
column9: and after much debate
column10: Dr. King had decided to lead people to Montgomery.

column1: Assistant Attorney General John Doar and former Florida governor LeRoy Collins
column2: representing President Lyndon Johnson
column3: went to Selma to meet with King and others at Richie Jean Jackson's house and privately urged King to postpone the march. The SCLC president told them that his conscience demanded that he proceed
column4: and that many movement supporters
column5: especially in SNCC
column6: would go ahead with the march even if he told them it should be called off. Collins suggested to King that he make a symbolic witness at the bridge
column7: then turn around and lead the marchers back to Selma. King told them that he would try to enact the plan provided that Collins could ensure that law enforcement would not attack them. Collins obtained this guarantee from Sheriff Clark and Al Lingo in exchange for a guarantee that King would follow a precise route drawn up by Clark.

column2: a day that would become known as "Turnaround Tuesday"
column3: Collins handed Dr. King the secretly agreed route. King led about 2

column9: even though the police unexpectedly stood aside to let them enter.As only SCLC leaders had been told in advance of the plan

column11: including those who had traveled long distances to participate and oppose police brutality. King asked them to remain in Selma for another march to take place after the injunction was lifted.

column2: three white Unitarian Universalist ministers in Selma for the march were attacked on the street and beaten with clubs by four KKK members. The worst injured was Reverend James Reeb from Boston. Fearing that Selma's public hospital would refuse to treat Reeb

column4: two hours away. Reeb died on Thursday

column1: James Reeb's death provoked mourning throughout the country

President Johnson called Reeb's widow and father to express his condolences (he would later invoke Reeb's memory when he delivered a draft of the Voting Rights Act to Congress).Blacks in Dallas County and the Black Belt mourned the death of Reeb
column3: as they had earlier mourned the death of Jimmie Lee Jackson. But many activists were bitter that the media and national political leaders expressed great concern over the murder of Reeb

column9: what are you saying?"

column1: Dr. King's credibility in the movement was shaken by the secret turnaround agreement. David Garrow notes that King publicly "waffled and dissembled" on how his final decision had been made. On some occasions King would inaccurately claim that "no pre-arranged agreement existed"
column2: but under oath before Judge Johnson
column3: he acknowledged that there had been a "tacit agreement". Criticism of King by radicals in the movement became increasingly pronounced
column4: with James Forman calling Turnaround Tuesday
column5: "a classic example of trickery against the people".

column1: Following the death of James Reeb
column2: a memorial service was held at the Brown's Chapel AME Church on March 15. Among those who addressed the packed congregation were Dr. King
column3: labor leader Walter Reuther
column4: and some clergymen. A picture of King
column5: Reuther
column6: Greek Orthodox Archbishop Iakovos and others in Selma for Reeb's memorial service appeared on the cover of Life magazine on March 26
column7: 1965. After the memorial service
column8: upon getting permission from the courts
column9: the leaders and attendees marched from the Brown's Chapel AME Church to the Dallas County Courthouse in Selma.

column1: With the second march turned and its organizers awaiting a judicial order to safely proceed
column2: Tuskegee Institute students
column3: led by Gwen Patton and Sammy Younge Jr.
column4: decided to open a "Second Front" by marching to the Alabama State Capitol and delivering a petition to Governor Wallace. They were quickly joined by James Forman and much of the SNCC staff from Selma. The SNCC members distrusted King more than ever after the "turnaround"
column5: and were eager to take a separate course.  On March 11
column6: SNCC began a series of demonstrations in Montgomery
column7: and put out a national call for others to join them. James Bevel
column8: SCLC's Selma leader
column9: followed them and discouraged their activities
column10: bringing him and SCLC into conflict with Forman and SNCC. Bevel accused Forman of trying to divert people from the Selma campaign and of abandoning nonviolent discipline. Forman accused Bevel of driving a wedge between the student movement and the local black churches. The argument was resolved only when both were arrested.On March 15 and 16
column11: SNCC led several hundred demonstrators
column15: in protests near the capitol complex. The Montgomery County sheriff's posse met them on horseback and drove them back
column16: whipping them. Against the objections of James Bevel
column17: some protesters threw bricks and bottles at police. At a mass meeting on the night of the 16th
column18: Forman "whipped the crowd into a frenzy" demanding that the President act to protect demonstrators
column20: "If we can't sit at the table of democracy
column21: we'll knock the fucking legs off."The New York Times featured the Montgomery confrontations on the front page the next day. Although Dr. King was concerned by Forman's violent rhetoric
column22: he joined him in leading a march of 2000 people in Montgomery to the Montgomery County courthouse.

column2: "City officials
column3: also worried by the violent turn of events ... apologized for the assault on SNCC protesters and invited King and Forman to discuss how to handle future protests in the city."  In the negotiations
column4: Montgomery officials agreed to stop using the county posse against protesters
column5: and to issue march permits to blacks for the first time.Governor Wallace did not negotiate
column6: however. He continued to have state police arrest any demonstrators who ventured onto Alabama State property of the capitol complex.

column2: seven Selma solidarity activists sat-in at the East Wing of the White House until arrested. Dozens of other protesters also tried to occupy the White House that weekend but were stopped by guards; they blocked Pennsylvania Avenue instead. On March 12
column3: President Johnson had an unusually belligerent meeting with a group of civil rights advocates including Bishop Paul Moore
column4: Reverend Robert Spike
column5: and SNCC representative H. Rap Brown. Johnson complained that the White House protests were disturbing his family. The activists were unsympathetic and demanded to know why he hadn't delivered the voting rights bill to Congress yet
column6: or sent federal troops to Alabama to protect the protesters. In this same period
column7: SNCC
column8: CORE
column9: and other groups continued to organize protests in more than eighty cities
column10: actions that included 400 people blocking the entrances and exits of the Los Angeles Federal Building.President Johnson told the press that he refused to be "blackjacked" into action by unruly "pressure groups". The next day he arranged a personal meeting with Governor Wallace
column11: urging him to use the Alabama National Guard to protect marchers. He also began preparing the final draft of his voting rights bill.On March 11
column12: Attorney General Katzenbach announced that the federal government was intending to prosecute local and state officials who were responsible for the attacks on the marchers on March 7. He would use an 1870 civil rights law as the basis for charges.

column1: ==== Johnson's decision and the Voting Rights Act ====

column2: the president convened a joint session of Congress
column3: outlined his new voting rights bill
column4: and demanded that they pass it. In a historic presentation carried nationally on live television
column5: making use of the largest media network
column6: Johnson praised the courage of African-American activists. He called Selma "a turning point in man's unending search for freedom" on a par with the Battle of Appomattox in the American Civil War. Johnson added that his entire Great Society program
column7: not only the voting rights bill
column8: was part of the Civil Rights Movement. He adopted language associated with Dr. King
column9: declaring that "it is not just Negroes
column10: but really it is all of us
column11: who must overcome the crippling legacy of bigotry and injustice. And we shall overcome." Afterward
column12: King sent a telegram to Johnson congratulating him for his speech
column13: calling it "the most moving eloquent unequivocal and passionate plea for human rights ever made by any president of this nation". Johnson's voting rights bill was formally introduced in Congress two days later.

column2: on Wednesday March 17
column3: Judge Johnson ruled in favor of the protesters
column4: saying their First Amendment right to march in protest could not be abridged by the state of Alabama:

column1: The law is clear that the right to petition one's government for the redress of grievances may be exercised in large groups . ... These rights may ... be exercised by marching
column2: even along public highways.

column1: Judge Johnson had sympathized with the protesters for some days
column2: but had withheld his order until he received an iron-clad commitment of enforcement from the White House. President Johnson had avoided such a commitment in sensitivity to the power of the state's rights movement
column3: and attempted to cajole Governor Wallace into protecting the marchers himself
column4: or at least giving the president permission to send troops. Finally
column5: seeing that Wallace had no intention of doing either
column6: the president gave his commitment to Judge Johnson on the morning of March 17
column7: and the judge issued his order the same day. To ensure that this march would not be as unsuccessful as the first two marches were
column8: the president federalized the Alabama National Guard on March 20 to escort the march from Selma
column9: The ground operation was supervised by Deputy U.S. Attorney General Ramsey Clark.  He also sent Joseph A Califano Jr.
column10: who at the time served as Special Assistant to the Secretary of Defense
column11: to outline the progress of the march. In a series of letters
column12: Califano reported on the march at regular intervals for the four days.On Sunday
column15: 000 people assembled at Brown Chapel A.M.E. Church to commence the trek to Montgomery. Most of the participants were black
column16: but some were white and some were Asian and Latino. Spiritual leaders of multiple races
column18: and creeds marched abreast with Dr. King
column21: Rabbis Abraham Joshua Heschel and Maurice Davis
column23: all of whom were depicted in a photo that has become famous. The Dutch Catholic priest Henri Nouwen joined the march on March 24.In 1965
column24: the road to Montgomery was four lanes wide going east from Selma
column25: then narrowed to two lanes through Lowndes County
column26: and widened to four lanes again at the Montgomery county border. Under the terms of Judge Johnson's order
column27: the march was limited to no more than 300 participants for the two days they were on the two-lane portion of Highway-80. At the end of the first day
column28: most of the marchers returned to Selma by bus and car
column29: leaving 300 to camp overnight and take up the journey the next day.

column2: 300 protesters marched through chilling rain across Lowndes County
column3: camping at three sites in muddy fields. At the time of the march
column4: the population of Lowndes County was 81% black and 19% white
column5: but not a single black was registered to vote. There were 2
column6: 240 whites registered to vote in Lowndes County
column7: a figure that represented 118% of the adult white population (in many Southern counties of that era it was common practice to retain white voters on the rolls after they died or moved away). On March 23
column8: Hundreds of black marchers wore kippot
column9: Jewish skullcaps
column10: to emulate the marching rabbis
column11: as Heschel was marching at the front of the crowd. The marchers called the kippot "freedom caps."On the morning of March 24
column12: the march crossed into Montgomery County and the highway widened again to four lanes. All day as the march approached the city
column13: additional marchers were ferried by bus and car to join the line. By evening
column14: several thousand marchers had reached the final campsite at the City of St. Jude
column15: a complex on the outskirts of Montgomery.

column1: That night on a makeshift stage
column2: a "Stars for Freedom" rally was held
column3: with singers Harry Belafonte
column4: Tony Bennett
column5: Frankie Laine
column6: Peter
column7: Paul and Mary
column8: Sammy Davis
column9: Jr.
column10: Joan Baez
column11: Nina Simone
column12: and The Chad Mitchell Trio all performing. Thousands more people continued to join the march.

column2: March 25
column4: 000 people marched from St. Jude to the steps of the State Capitol Building where King delivered the speech How Long
column5: Not Long. He said:

column1: The end we seek is a society at peace with itself
column2: a society that can live with its conscience. ... I know you are asking today
column3: How long will it take? I come to say to you this afternoon however difficult the moment
column4: however frustrating the hour
column5: it will not be long.

column2: King and the marchers approached the entrance to the capitol with a petition for Governor Wallace. A line of state troopers blocked the door. One announced that the governor was not in. Undeterred
column3: the marchers remained at the entrance until one of Wallace's secretaries appeared and took the petition.Later that night
column4: Viola Liuzzo
column5: a white mother of five from Detroit who had come to Alabama to support voting rights for blacks
column6: was assassinated by Ku Klux Klan members while she was ferrying marchers back to Selma from Montgomery. Among the Klansmen in the car from which the shots were fired was FBI informant Gary Rowe. Afterward
column7: the FBI's COINTELPRO operation spread false rumors that Liuzzo was a member of the Communist Party and had abandoned her children to have sexual relationships with African-American activists.

column1: The third Selma march received national and international coverage. It was reported that it publicized the marchers' message without harassment by police and segregation supporters. Gaining more widespread support from other civil rights organizations in the area
column2: this third march was considered an overall success
column3: with greater degree of influence on the public. Subsequently
column4: voter registration drives were organized in black-majority areas across the South
column5: but it took time to get the target population to sign up.

column1: U.S. Representative William Louis Dickinson made two speeches to Congress on March 30 and April 27
column2: saying that there was alcohol abuse
column3: bribery
column4: and widespread sexual license among the marchers. Religious leaders present at the marches denied the allegations
column5: and local and national journalists found no grounds for his accounts. The allegations of segregation supporters were collected in Robert M. Mikell's pro-segregationist book Selma (Charlotte

column2: Martin Luther King Jr. was promoting an economic boycott of Alabama products to put pressure on the State to integrate schools and employment. In an action under development for some time
column3: Hammermill paper company announced the opening of a major plant in Selma
column4: Alabama; this came during the height of violence in early 1965. On February 4
column6: the company announced plans for construction of a $35 million plant
column7: allegedly touting the "fine reports the company had received about the character of the community and its people".On March 26
column9: the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee called for a national boycott of Hammermill paper products
column10: until the company reversed what SNCC described as racist policies. The SCLC joined in support of the boycott. In cooperation with SCLC
column11: student members of Oberlin College Action for Civil Rights
column12: joined with SCLC members to conduct picketing and a sit-in at Hammermill's Erie
column13: Pennsylvania headquarters. The company called a meeting of the corporate leadership
column15: and Oberlin student leadership. Their discussions led to Hammermill executives signing an agreement to support integration in Alabama.

column1: The marches had a powerful effect in Washington. After witnessing TV coverage of "Bloody Sunday"
column2: President Lyndon Baines Johnson met with Governor George Wallace in Washington to discuss the civil rights situation in his state. He tried to persuade Wallace to stop the state harassment of the protesters. Two nights later
column3: on March 15
column5: Johnson presented a bill to a joint session of Congress. The bill was passed that summer and signed by Johnson as the Voting Rights Act on August 6
column6: 1965.Johnson's televised speech before Congress was carried nationally; it was considered to be a watershed moment for the civil rights movement. He said:

column1: Even if we pass this bill
column2: the battle will not be over. What happened in Selma is part of a far larger movement which reaches into every section and state of America. It is the effort of American Negroes to secure for themselves the full blessings of American life. Their cause must be our cause
column3: too
column4: because it is not just Negroes but really it is all of us who must overcome the crippling legacy of bigotry and injustice.  And we shall overcome.

column1: Many in the Civil Rights Movement cheered the speech and were emotionally moved that after so long
column2: and so hard a struggle
column3: a President was finally willing to defend voting rights for blacks. According to C.T. Vivian
column4: an SCLC activist who was with King at Richie Jean Jackson's home when the speech was broadcast

column1: I looked over ... and Martin was very quietly sitting in the chair
column2: and a tear ran down his cheek.  It was a victory like none other. It was an affirmation of the movement.

column1: Many others in the movement remained skeptical of the White House
column2: believing that Johnson was culpable for having allowed violence against the movement in the early months of the campaign and was not a reliable supporter. Neither Jimmie Lee Jackson's murderer
column3: nor Reverend Reeb's was ever prosecuted by the federal government. J.L. Chestnut
column4: reflecting the view of many Selma activists
column5: feared that the president had "outfoxed" and "co-opted" King and the SCLC. James Forman quipped that by quoting "We Shall Overcome"
column6: Johnson had simply "spoiled a good song". Such grassroots activists were more determined than ever to remain independent in their political organizing.

column1: Before the march to Montgomery concluded
column2: SNCC staffers Stokely Carmichael and Cleveland Sellers committed themselves to registering voters in Lowndes County for the next year. Their efforts resulted in the creation of the Lowndes County Freedom Organization
column3: an independent third party.The bill was signed by President Johnson in an August 6 ceremony attended by Amelia Boynton and many other civil rights leaders and activists. This act prohibited most of the unfair practices used to prevent blacks from registering to vote
column4: and provided for federal registrars to go to Alabama and other states with a history of voting-related discrimination to ensure that the law was implemented by overseeing registration and elections.

column1: In the early years of the Act
column2: overall progress was slow
column3: with local registrars continuing to use their power to deny African Americans voting access. In most Alabama counties
column4: for example
column5: registration continued to be limited to two days per month. The United States Civil Rights Commission acknowledged that "The Attorney General moved slowly in exercising his authority to designate counties for examiners ... he acted only in counties where he had ample evidence to support the belief that there would be intentional and flagrant violation of the Act." Dr. King demanded that federal registrars be sent to every county covered by the Act
column6: but Attorney General Katzenbach refused.In the summer of 1965
column7: a well-funded SCLC decided to join SNCC and CORE in massive on-the-ground voter registration programs in the South. The Civil Rights Commission described this as a major contribution to expanding black voters in 1965
column8: and the Justice Department acknowledged leaning on the work of "local organizations" in the movement to implement the Act. SCLC and SNCC were temporarily able to mend past differences through collaboration in the Summer Community Organization & Political Education project. Ultimately
column9: their coalition foundered on SCLC's commitment to nonviolence and (at the time) the Democratic Party. Many activists worried that President Johnson still sought to appease Southern whites
column10: and some historians support this view.By March 1966
column11: nearly 11
column12: 000 blacks had registered to vote in Selma
column14: 000 whites were registered. More blacks would register by November
column15: when their goal was to replace County Sheriff Jim Clark; his opponent was Wilson Baker
column16: for whom they had respect. In addition
column17: five blacks ran for office in Dallas County. Rev. P. H. Lewis
column18: pastor of Brown Chapel A.M.E. Church
column19: ran for state representative on the Democratic ticket. David Ellwanger
column20: a brother of Rev. Joseph Ellwanger of Birmingham
column21: who led supporters in Selma in 1965
column22: challenged incumbent state senator Walter C. Givhan (d. 1976)
column23: a fierce segregationist and a power in the state senate. First elected to the state senate in 1954
column24: Givhan retained his seat for six terms
column25: even after redistricting that preceded the 1966 election.In November 1966
column27: that "I am attempting to do the least I can do safely without upsetting the civil rights groups." Katzenbach did concentrate examiners and observers in Selma for the "high-visibility" election between incumbent County Sheriff Jim Clark and Wilson Baker
column28: who had earned the grudging respect of many local residents and activists. With 11
column29: 000 blacks added to the voting rolls in Selma by March 1966
column31: turning Clark out of office. Clark later was prosecuted and convicted of drug smuggling and served a prison sentence. The US Civil Rights Commission said that the murders of activists
column33: had been a major impediment to voter registration.Overall
column34: the Justice Department assigned registrars to six of Alabama's 24 Black Belt counties during the late 1960s
column35: and to fewer than one-fifth of all the Southern counties covered by the Act. Expansion of enforcement grew gradually
column36: and the jurisdiction of the Act was expanded through a series of amendments beginning in 1970. An important change was made in 1972
column37: when Congress passed an amendment that discrimination could be determined by "effect" rather than by trying to prove "intent". Thus
column38: if county or local practices resulted in a significant minority population being unable to elect candidates of their choice
column39: the practices were considered to be discriminatory in effect.

column2: there were a total of 53
column3: 336 black voters registered in the state of Alabama; three decades later
column4: there were 537
column6: a tenfold increase.

column2: the 54-mile Selma to Montgomery National Historic Trail was designated and is preserved by the National Park Service. As part of the National Historic Trail
column3: the National Park Service operates two interpretive centers (Selma and Lowndes County). It is planning to operate a Montgomery center to be located on the campus of Alabama State University.

column2: both houses of Congress voted for a resolution to award Congressional Gold Medals to the "foot soldiers" of the Selma campaign. In a later ceremony
column3: two dozen individuals in Selma received certificates. Barack Obama signed the resolution in law on March 7.  The award ceremony officially took place on February 24
column5: at the US Capitol.  Surviving marchers John Lewis and Frederick Reese accepted medals on behalf of the Selma marchers

column2: many marches have commemorated the events of Bloody Sunday

column4: and currently known as the Selma Bridge Crossing Jubilee. In March 1975
column5: Coretta Scott King
column6: the widow of Martin Luther King Jr.
column7: led four thousand marchers commemorating Bloody Sunday. On its 30th anniversary
column8: Rep. John Lewis
column9: former president of Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee and a prominent activist during the Selma to Montgomery marches
column10: said
column11: "It's gratifying to come back and see the changes that have occurred; to see the number of registered voters and the number of Black elected officials in the state of Alabama to be able to walk with other members of Congress that are African Americans."On the 40th anniversary of Bloody Sunday
column15: again marched across Edmund Pettus Bridge. Also
column17: the Olympic torch made its way across the bridge with its carrier
column20: to symbolize how far the South has come. When Young spoke at the Brown Chapel A.M.E. Church as part of the torch ceremony
column22: "We couldn't have gone to Atlanta with the Olympic Games if we hadn't come through Selma a long time ago."In March 2015
column23: on the 50th anniversary of Bloody Sunday
column26: delivered a speech at the foot of the bridge and then
column27: along with other U.S. political figures such as former U.S. President George W. Bush and Representative John Lewis and Civil Rights Movement activists such as Amelia Boynton Robinson (at Obama's side in a wheelchair)
column28: led a march across the bridge. An estimated 40
column29: 000 people attended to commemorate the 1965 march

column1: Montgomery was one of four state capitals chosen for a Greening Americas Capitals Grant
column2: a project of the Partnership for Sustainable Communities between the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)
column3: the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development
column4: and the U.S. Department of Transportation. Beginning in 2011
column5: EPA and community groups developed the study through consultations and a 3-day design workshops
column6: aided by nationally acclaimed urban planners.

column1: The Montgomery portion of the Selma to Montgomery trail was being improved through a multimillion-dollar investment in order to enhance the trail and related neighborhoods. The city chose a section that passes through a "historically significant African-American neighborhood". Projects planned to improve design and sustainability include infill development
column2: resurfacing
column3: pedestrian improvements
column4: environmental improvements including new trees and green-screens
column5: and drainage improvements. In addition
column6: many information panels have been installed
column7: as well as several permanent public art displays that are tied to the march.The work in Montgomery is related to a larger multi-agency effort since 2009 between the Alabama Department of Environmental Management (ADEM)
column8: EPA and the National Park Service to improve areas along the National Historic Voting Rights Trail to enable local communities to thrive. The US 80 corridor has been described in an EPA summary as a "54-mile corridor of high unemployment
column9: health issues
column10: lower educational and economic achievements
column11: and severe rural isolation". Among the serious environmental issues identified by EPA has been the presence of active and abandoned gas stations along the highway
column12: with potential contamination from petroleum leaks from underground storage sites. A site in Montgomery had been identified as a problem
column13: and EPA conducted additional assessments since the beginning of the project. Cleanup of the Montgomery site was scheduled to be completed in 2011. In addition
column14: the agencies have sponsored community engagement to develop plans related to community goals. Since 2010
column15: federal teams have met with community leaders in Selma

column1: Eyes on the Prize (1987) was a 14-hour PBS documentary narrated by Julian Bond and produced by PBS. The sixth episode
column2: "Bridge to Freedom"
column3: explores the Selma to Montgomery marches. The series and its producer won six Emmies
column4: the Peabody Award
column5: and the duPont-Columbia Gold Baton award for excellence in journalism
column6: and it was nominated for an Academy Award.

column2: Lord
column3: Selma (1999)
column4: the first dramatic feature film based on events surrounding the Selma to Montgomery marches
column5: is a Disney made-for-TV movie shown on ABC television. Critical reception varied.

column2: a 2014 American film directed by Ava DuVernay
column3: features the historic figures who developed the voting rights campaign in Selma and led the Selma to Montgomery marches. The film starred David Oyelowo as Martin Luther King Jr.
column4: Tom Wilkinson as President Lyndon B. Johnson
column5: Common as James Bevel
column6: and Tim Roth as Governor George Wallace. It was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Picture
column7: won for best song
column8: and received highly favorable reviews
column9: despite being criticized for the inaccurate portrayal of President Johnson as obstructing the advancement of civil rights.

column1: March (2013) is a three-part graphic novel autobiography written by Congressman John Lewis and published by Top Shelf Productions. It begins with his and fellow civil rights activists' beating and gassing at the hands of Alabama state troopers on the Edmund Pettus Bridge. Written by Lewis and his congressional aide
column2: Andrew Aydin
column3: and illustrated by Nate Powell
column4: the first book in the series was published in August 2013.
